scenario_draft.scenario: The Artisan Notebook Swap at the Creative Leadership Seminar

participants.name: You
participants.profile: Facilitator attending a multi-day creative leadership seminar

participants.name: Bob
participants.profile: Fellow facilitator attending the same seminar

behavior_choices.keep_item: Keep the artisan notebook you received during the seminar registration
behavior_choices.trade_item: Trade your notebook with Bob, who received a notebook with a different design

scenario_draft.description: At the start of a three-day creative leadership seminar, each facilitator receives a hand-bound artisan notebook as a welcome gift. The notebooks are all unique, featuring a variety of colors and cover illustrations inspired by nature. You receive one with a forest green cover and an embossed fern motif. Later, during a break, you notice that Bob, another facilitator, has a notebook with a deep maroon cover and a stylized mountain illustration. Bob mentions he has always preferred green tones and politely asks if you would consider swapping notebooks. The organizers mention that exchanging notebooks is completely optional and simply meant to encourage networking and conversation. You must now decide whether to keep your forest green, fern-embossed notebook or exchange it for Bob's maroon, mountain-themed one.
scenario_draft.payoff_matrix_description: Your choice will determine which unique notebook you take home as your seminar keepsake. There is no monetary compensation or external reward; the organizers are interested in understanding how attendees value their original gift compared to an equally distinctive alternative.

narrative_feedback: The scenario is realistic and coherent; the context of a creative leadership seminar and the distribution of unique artisan notebooks is plausible and well described.
Participants' names ('You', 'Bob') are correctly used, and their roles as facilitators at the seminar are plausible and consistently integrated.
There is no mention of any prior relationship between 'You' and 'Bob'; the interaction is appropriately limited to the context of the seminar.
The behavior choices ('keep_item', 'trade_item') accurately reflect the available strategies in the scenario.

The narrative does a good job of masking the underlying Endowment Effect game structure by focusing on the uniqueness of the notebooks and the optional nature of the exchange, rather than explicitly framing it as a test of ownership bias.

One minor point: the participant job titles in the prompt are listed as 'spiritual director', but the scenario uses 'facilitator'. If strict adherence to the job title is required, consider updating 'facilitator' to 'spiritual director' for consistency with the participant details provided in the prompt.
payoff_feedback: Scenario draft is missing required keys ('behavior_choices', 'payoff_matrix_description') or payoff_matrix is not a dictionary for payoff validation.

scenario_draft.scenario: Ceramic Planter Exchange at the Interfaith Retreat

participants.name: You
participants.profile: Spiritual director attending a regional interfaith retreat

participants.name: Bob
participants.profile: Fellow spiritual director participating in the same retreat

behavior_choices.keep_item: Keep the unique ceramic planter you received during the retreat welcome
behavior_choices.trade_item: Trade your ceramic planter with Bob, who was given a different design

scenario_draft.description: At the annual regional interfaith retreat, each spiritual director is welcomed with a handcrafted ceramic planter—each piece is distinct in color and motif. Upon arrival, you receive a deep blue planter adorned with a subtle leaf pattern. Later, during a group reflection, you notice that Bob, another spiritual director, has a vibrant yellow planter featuring a geometric design. During a break, Bob mentions his fondness for cooler tones and politely asks if you'd consider exchanging planters. The organizers emphasize that the planters are intended as personal mementos, but exchanging them is entirely optional and meant to foster meaningful connections. You must now decide whether to keep your blue leaf-patterned planter or trade it for Bob's yellow geometric one.
scenario_draft.payoff_matrix_description: Your decision will determine which unique planter you take home as a keepsake. There is no monetary value assigned, and no additional incentives or consequences—organizers are simply interested in how participants value the specific planter they received compared to an equally attractive alternative.

narrative_feedback: The scenario is realistic and coherent: the setting of an interfaith retreat, the distribution of unique planters, and the optional exchange are all plausible and well-integrated.
Participants' names and roles are correctly used: 'You' and 'Bob' are both spiritual directors, and there is no mention of any prior relationship beyond being fellow attendees.
The behavior choices ('keep_item' and 'trade_item') accurately reflect the possible actions in the scenario.
The narrative avoids any mention of friendship or family ties, maintaining appropriate neutrality between participants.
The story masks the Endowment Effect reasonably well by focusing on the uniqueness and sentimental value of the planters, rather than explicitly referencing psychological ownership or bias.

The only minor suggestion is to ensure that the narrative does not overemphasize the uniqueness or sentimental value in a way that might tip off participants to the underlying bias being studied. However, as written, the masking is subtle and appropriate.
payoff_feedback: Scenario draft is missing required keys ('behavior_choices', 'payoff_matrix_description') or payoff_matrix is not a dictionary for payoff validation.

scenario_draft.scenario: Ceramic Planter Swap at the Community Green Fair

participants.name: You
participants.profile: Community member attending a local green fair

participants.name: Bob
participants.profile: Fellow attendee and gardening hobbyist

behavior_choices.keep_item: Keep the unique ceramic planter you received at registration
behavior_choices.trade_item: Trade your ceramic planter with Bob, who received a different design

scenario_draft.description: At the annual Community Green Fair, each guest is welcomed with a handcrafted ceramic planter—no two are exactly alike. Upon arrival, you receive a deep blue planter with a subtle leaf pattern, while Bob, another garden enthusiast you meet at a workshop, has a sunburst-yellow planter with a geometric motif. During a break, Bob mentions he's always preferred cool tones and wonders if you'd be interested in swapping. The event encourages interaction but makes it clear that exchanging planters is purely voluntary, and each piece is meant as a personal keepsake. Now, you must decide whether to keep your blue leaf-patterned planter or trade it for Bob's yellow geometric one.
scenario_draft.payoff_matrix_description: There is no monetary or competitive incentive; your decision only changes which unique planter you take home. Organizers are simply interested in how attendees value the particular planter they initially received compared to an equally attractive alternative.

narrative_feedback: The scenario is realistic and coherent: attending a community fair and receiving unique planters is plausible, and the interaction is natural.

There is no mention of a prior relationship between 'You' and 'Bob', which is correct.
The behavior choices ('keep_item' and 'trade_item') accurately reflect the possible actions in the scenario.
The narrative does a good job of masking the Endowment Effect structure, as it focuses on personal preference and voluntary exchange rather than explicitly on ownership bias.
To fully align with the requirements, update the participant profiles to 'spiritual director' for both 'You' and 'Bob'.

participants.name: Alex
participants.profile: Fellow garden enthusiast at the same symposium

behavior_choices.keep_item: Keep the artisan tea tin you received as a welcome gift
behavior_choices.trade_item: Trade your tea tin with Alex, who received a different blend

scenario_draft.description: At the start of a two-day horticultural symposium, every attendee is presented with a beautifully packaged artisan tea tin featuring a unique blend inspired by botanical gardens. You receive 'Rosemary Citrus' (herbal with a hint of lemon), while Alex receives 'Lavender Meadow' (floral with chamomile). During a break, Alex mentions a fondness for citrus flavors and asks if you would consider swapping blends. The event organizers quietly encourage exchanges to foster conversation but stress that the gifts are personal and exchanges are entirely optional. Now, you must decide whether to keep your 'Rosemary Citrus' tea or trade it for Alex's 'Lavender Meadow.'
scenario_draft.payoff_matrix_description: There is no monetary value attached to your choice, nor are there any additional rewards. Your decision simply determines which unique tea blend you take home from the symposium. Organizers are interested in how attendees value the specific item they initially receive compared to an equally appealing alternative.

scenario_draft.scenario: The Retreat Keepsake Dilemma: Personal Value in Spiritual Tools

participants.name: You
participants.profile: spiritual director

participants.name: Bob
participants.profile: spiritual director

behavior_choices.keep_item: Keep the meditation journal you received
behavior_choices.trade_item: Trade your meditation journal for the gratitude stone Bob received

scenario_draft.description: At the conclusion of a week-long spiritual retreat, each participant receives either a meditation journal or a gratitude stone, assigned at random as a keepsake for daily spiritual reflection. You receive a meditation journal. As the group gathers to depart, Bob, another spiritual director who received a gratitude stone, approaches and suggests a swap: he offers you his gratitude stone in exchange for your meditation journal. Both items are described as equally valuable and intended for similar reflective practices. The retreat organizers note that the choice is entirely personal and that there are no right or wrong answers. You must decide whether to keep the meditation journal you were given or to exchange it for Bob's gratitude stone.
scenario_draft.payoff_matrix_description: There are no explicit monetary rewards or penalties; your choice determines which spiritual tool you will take home. Organizers are interested in how participants value the item they received compared to an equally useful alternative.

narrative_feedback: The scenario is realistic and coherent: the setting of a spiritual retreat and the distribution of keepsakes is plausible, and the story flows logically.
Participants' names ('You', 'Bob') and roles ('spiritual director') are correctly and plausibly integrated. There is no suggestion of a prior relationship beyond their shared professional role.
No prior relationship is implied between 'You' and 'Bob'; the narrative simply states they are both spiritual directors at the same retreat.
The behavior choices ('keep_item', 'trade_item') accurately reflect the available strategies in the scenario.

The narrative masks the Endowment Effect structure reasonably well: it frames the decision as a personal choice between two equally valuable spiritual tools, without overtly signaling the psychological bias under study.

The only minor suggestion is to clarify that all participants are spiritual directors or to specify that this is a retreat for spiritual directors, as it is slightly unusual for both named participants to have the same specialized role unless the retreat is for professionals. However, this is not strictly necessary and does not detract from the scenario's plausibility.
